title: Relative Clauses All 2
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2, B1whoB2, B1whomB2, B1nothingB2 or B1whatB2.

sentence: In this book there're a lot of words
I don't know the meaning of.
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer back to a noun (words), so we cannot use 'what'. And we can leave out the relative pronoun because it's the object of the relative clause.

sentence: 'You can't always get
you need.' That's
my experience tells me about life.
explain: Corr: Here the relative pronoun comes immediately after a verb (get), so there's no noun to refer back to, and so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.
Corr: Here the relative pronoun comes immediately after a verb (is), so there's no noun to refer back to, and so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.

sentence: Unfortunately, I still haven't won back the money
I lost at poker.
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. Here we refer back to a noun (money) so we need 'which' or 'that'. But we can leave out the relative pronoun because it's the object of the relative clause.

sentence: 'Was that all
she told you about this incident?' 'Yes, or at least, that was
she wanted me to believe.'
explain: Corr: that, which or nothing. We refer back to a noun (all), so we cannot use 'what', only 'which' or 'that' are correct. However, if there's 'all' in the sentence, 'that' is a better solution. Or, as the relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause, we can leave it out.
Corr: what. Here there's no noun after the verb (be), so we cannot refer back to it with 'which' or 'that'. Therefore only 'what' is correct.

sentence: I tried to sit calmly because the chair on
I was sitting was quite shaky.
explain: Corr: which. There's a preposition so we need to use a relative pronoun and we refer back to a noun (chair), so we can use only 'which'. 'that' is not used after prepositions.

sentence: The books
stood on the shelf looked quite boring. The one
I took off was about Rousseau.
explain: Corr: which or that. The relative pronoun here refers back to a noun so it cannot be 'what'. And we cannot leave it out because it's the subject of the relative clause.
Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer back to a noun (one), so we cannot use 'what'. As the relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause, we can leave it out.

sentence: I don't really like the teachers
teach at this school.
explain: Corr: who or that. We refer back to persons, so we need to use 'who' or 'that'. And we cannot leave it out because it's the subject of the relative clause.

sentence: The route
my satnav suggested was not exactly
I thought to be the best.
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer back to a noun (route), so we cannot use 'what'. We can leave out the relative pronoun because it's the object of the relative clause.
Corr: what. Here there's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'. There's is just the verb 'was', which is not followed by a noun. That's why only 'what' is correct.

sentence: In this game, the monsters
I kill can come back to life.
explain: Corr: which, that, who or nothing. We refer back to a noun (monsters), so we cannot use 'what'. As the relative pronoun is the object of the relative clause, we can leave it out.

sentence: My wife didn't like the villages through
we drove while we were in France.
explain: Corr: which. We refer back to a noun (villages), so we cannot use 'what'. As there's a preposition, we cannot use 'that'.
